Award.AwardTitle: Physics near the metal-insulator transition in magnetic thin-films
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
For the traditional transition-metal band ferromagnets (Fe, Co and Ni) where the aligned moments are successfully described by unequally populated majority (spin-up) and minority (spin-down) bands, the ultimate fate of magnetism, when the itinerancy is compromised by disorder to such an extent that the conductivity drops to zero at critical disorder, is unknown. This project addresses the consequences of systematically reducing the thickness of two-dimensional (2D) magnetic thin films (thereby increasing disorder strength) until the insulating magnetic state is attained. A custom high-vacuum deposition system with in situ electronic/magnetic characterization capability prevents sample deterioration due to air exposure and is essential for this work. The project's focus on tuning a variety of magnetic systems through critical disorder is expected to provide valuable insight into the properties of thin-film magnetic insulators and help answer questions about (1) the disorder induced high rate of inelastic scattering of electrons off of spin waves, (2) the ordering of local moments, (3) the role of granularity, and (4) the emergence of new phases. This project will support the education of PhD students in advanced vacuum deposition and electronic/magnetic characterization techniques, which have already proven to be excellent training for productive scientific careers in academic and technology settings. Pursuit of these studies will improve prediction of the magnetic properties of ultrathin magnetic materials and extend knowledge of the behavior of bulk magnetism in the very different environments experienced at surfaces and interfaces.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Magnetism in the transition metal elements such as iron is not fully understood. In the itinerant (traveling) electron scenario there are more spin-up (north pole up) than spin down (north pole down) electrons and the net difference gives rise to the magnetic properties that, for example, cause an iron compass needle to align with the earth's magnetic field. The situation rapidly becomes more complicated when the itinerant electrons scatter off impurities and/or defects, losing their itinerancy and eventually becoming localized (fixed in place) when the disorder strength, as characterized by the density of scattering sites, is at a critical value. This project will pursue experimental studies of magnetic thin films in which disorder can be systematically increased and the effect on magnetism studied. At critical disorder, itinerancy is lost and the magnetic metal becomes an insulator with localized electrons accompanied by the likely appearance of new magnetic phases with unusual spin alignments. This project will support the education of PhD students in advanced vacuum deposition and electronic/magnetic characterization techniques, which have already proven to be excellent training for productive scientific careers in academic and technology settings. The expected increased physical understanding of magnetism in thin films from these studies will be relevant to technological applications which incorporate ultrathin magnetic films into multilayer configurations for magnetic recording, spin generation, spin manipulation and/or spin detection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CREX: Novel physics at the interfaces of Van der Waals crystals and semiconductors

A Van der Waals (VdW) crystal comprises two-dimensional atomic planes sequentially stacked in sandwich like structures often having remarkable properties. A familiar example is graphite which consists of honey-combed layers of single atom thick carbon (graphene) neatly arranged in loosely coupled ordered layers which can be separated from each other in an exfoliation process. Interestingly there are a variety of related quasi two-dimensional VdW crystals which have similar properties and harbor a wide spectrum of physical properties including magnetism, superconductivity and charge density wave formation. We have studied numerous combinations of freshly exfoliated VdW crystals in intimate contact with widely available semiconductors such as silicon and gallium arsenide. The electrical properties at the interfaces of these heterostructures are extremely sensitive to the parameters describing the phases of the VdW electrode and to external parameters such as temperature, electric field and magnetic field.

Panels (a)-(c) of the accompanying figure depict a band energy diagram which forms a barrier to the flow of electrons at the junction of a VdW metal (left side) connected to a semiconductor (right side). The asymmetry of the barrier (a.k.a. Schottky junction) allows electrons in response to applied forward bias voltages (VF) to flow more easily from right to left than from left to right for reverse bias voltages (VR). Such asymmetric junction diodes are ubiquitous and well understood in semiconductor technology.  Panel (d) shows the current voltage characteristic of a high-Tc superconductor (Tc = 85K) reflecting the diode characteristics illustrated in panels (a)-(c) in addition to a tunneling feature (see inset) reflecting details of the superconductivity in the superconductor.

Our research centers on using a variety of freshly exfoliated flakes of Van der Waals (VdW) layered crystals harboring exotic phase transitions such as superconductivity (see figure), conducting surface states or charge density wave (CDW) transitions. These phase transitions induce changes in bulk electronic properties which are uniquely manifested at the interface by the temperature-dependent energy parameters shown schematically in the figure. The observed common features for the variety of materials we have studied present a unifying theme embracing the nature of quantum phase transitions at layered VdW material interfaces and promises integration of new functionalities into existing semiconductor technology.

The intellectual merit and broader impact of the CREX work summarized here and the work under the parent grant (Federal Award ID: 1305783) titled ?Physics near the metal-insulator transition in magnetic thin-films? with duration from 01 June 2013 to 31 May 2016 includes: publication of 24 refereed manuscripts, delivery of 23 invited presentations by the PI, graduation of 5 PhD students, numerous student contributed presentations, and service as a referee, panel/proposal reviewer and associate editor for Reviews of Modern Physics.
